comment_text.mn131:1.1: A favorite of meditators, this discourse takes a distinctive set of verses as a template for explaining the aspect of meditation called vipassanā, commonly rendered “insight”; for why I use “discernment” see DN 14:1.37.5 and note. The next three discourses explain the same verses on different occasions, with MN 133 offering a complementary explanation.
comment_text.mn131:3.2: To “anticipate” (paṭikaṅkhe) is not always bad. A mendicant ought to “anticipate” dangers (pāṭikaṅkhitabba, AN 4.122:1.1 = MN 67:14.2); Nālaka “anticipates” the arrival of the Buddha (patikkhaṁ, Snp 3.11:19.4); and an arahant “awaits their time” (kālaṁ kaṅkhati, SN 2.29:15.4). The verse here has a specific application in meditation, which is explained below.
comment_text.mn131:3.5: Here “phenomenon” (dhamma) means anything that is directly knowable (see MN 133:17.9). | The two verses run on here, as indicated by the ca linking this line with the previous.
comment_text.mn131:3.6: For tattha tattha as “in every case” see eg. DN 30:2.1.3, and compare tato tattha vipassati at Snp 5.15:4.4.
comment_text.mn131:3.7: At Thag 14.1:5.1, this phrase refers to the mind developed in meditation on love and compassion, while at Snp 5.19:19.1 it refers to Nibbana. In both cases, as here, it is the object of the verb, not an adverb.
comment_text.mn131:4.2: Samanvāneti is unique in early Pali, but the similar samānayi is found at DN 30:1.33.4 and Thig 12.1:10.2 in the sense of “reunite, bring together”. “Muster” means both to bring together and to arouse. | SN 22.79 makes it clear that “in the past” means “in a past life”.
comment_text.mn131:8.1: Dhammesu (“phenomena”) is plural here, whereas in the verse it is singular. Sanskrit fragments, however, have plural in the verse as well.

translation_text.mn131:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn131:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn131:2.1: “I shall teach you the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.
translation_text.mn131:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn131:3.6: you clearly discern in every case.
translation_text.mn131:3.9: Today’s the day to keenly work—
translation_text.mn131:3.10: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
translation_text.mn131:3.11: For there is no bargain to be struck
translation_text.mn131:3.12: with Death and his mighty horde.
translation_text.mn131:3.13: One who keenly meditates like this,
translation_text.mn131:3.15: that’s who has one fine night—
translation_text.mn131:4.1: And how do you run back to the past?
translation_text.mn131:4.2: You muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’
translation_text.mn131:4.3: That’s how you run back to the past.
translation_text.mn131:5.1: And how do you not run back to the past?
translation_text.mn131:5.2: You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘I had such form in the past.’ … ‘I had such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the past.’
translation_text.mn131:5.3: That’s how you don’t run back to the past.
translation_text.mn131:6.1: And how do you anticipate the future?
translation_text.mn131:6.2: You muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’
translation_text.mn131:6.3: That’s how you anticipate the future.
translation_text.mn131:7.1: And how do you not anticipate the future?
translation_text.mn131:7.2: You don’t muster delight there, thinking: ‘May I have such form in the future.’ … ‘May I have such feeling … perception … choice … consciousness in the future.’
translation_text.mn131:7.3: That’s how you don’t anticipate the future.
translation_text.mn131:8.1: And how do you falter amid presently arisen phenomena?
translation_text.mn131:8.2: It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn131:8.3: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
translation_text.mn131:8.7: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
translation_text.mn131:8.8: That’s how you falter amid presently arisen phenomena.
translation_text.mn131:9.1: And how do you not falter amid presently arisen phenomena?
translation_text.mn131:9.2: It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn131:9.3: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
translation_text.mn131:9.7: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
translation_text.mn131:9.8: That’s how you don’t falter amid presently arisen phenomena.
translation_text.mn131:10.6: you clearly discern in every case.
translation_text.mn131:10.9: Today’s the day to keenly work—
translation_text.mn131:10.10: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
translation_text.mn131:10.11: For there is no bargain to be struck
translation_text.mn131:10.12: with Death and his mighty horde.
translation_text.mn131:10.13: One who keenly meditates like this,
translation_text.mn131:10.15: that’s who has one fine night—
translation_text.mn131:11.1: And that’s what I meant when I said: ‘I shall teach you the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.’”
translation_text.mn131:11.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn131:11.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
